body: We could implement something similar to the system property we support for execution conditions described here: https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#extensions-conditions-deactivation
@jportner-hw Would that work for you, e.g. by setting a system property?

Hi @marcphilipp . 
Would that system property name be configurable by us? If so we could use `intellij.debug.agent` which is set to true during debugging in IntelliJ to disable the Timeout.

If the system property name was defined by JUnit we could edit our "Run/Debug configuration" in IntelliJ to include it. I think the user configurable system property would be preferred so it could just be defined in our usage of Timeout and not force developers to make the change in IntelliJ.

> Would that system property name be configurable by us?

How would that make things easier?

Wouldn't we then need a system property (or JUnit Platform "configuration parameter") to set the name of the other system property, thereby forcing you to set two things?
I'm wondering whether we should simply deactivate timeouts if we can autodetect that a debugger is connected. Is there really a use case for debugging with active timeouts? ðŸ¤”

> I'm wondering whether we should simply deactivate timeouts if we can autodetect that a debugger is connected. 

I agree. As the OP pointed out, JUnit 4's `org.junit.rules.DisableOnDebug.isDebugging(List<String>)` seems like a pretty good way to achieve that.

> Is there really a use case for debugging with active timeouts? ðŸ¤”

I doubt it.

I wonder if we should consider doing anything for `assertTimeout*()` as well -- perhaps not, but worth considering nonetheless.

Yup. I'm happy if you implement the easy solution of just disabling `@Timeout` when a debugger is connected. "-Xdebug" jvm argument.
I can't think of a reason why someone would want to timeout while debugging.

> > Would that system property name be configurable by us?
> 
> How would that make things easier?
> 
> Wouldn't we then need a system property (or JUnit Platform "configuration parameter") to set the name of the other system property, thereby forcing you to set two things?

I was thinking something like `@Timeout(disabledWithSystemProperty="intellij.debug.agent")`
But like other people have replied maybe it's better to just take the simple approach of disabling timeout by default if debugging.

rename.from: @Timeout introduced in 5.5.0 does not support debugging

body:
**Team Decision:** Introduce a new `junit.jupiter.execution.timeout.mode` configuration parameter to configure when timeouts are applied. There are three modes: `enabled`, `disabled`, `disabled_on_debug`. By default it would be `enabled`.

@jportner-hw This way, you could add that to `junit-platform.properties` and comment it out or uncomment it as needed. Would that work for you?
